title: Brexit trade deal: What does it mean for UK businesses? - BBC News

segments.text: The post Brexit trade landscape continues to evolve
as businesses adapt to new rules and regulations
Exporters face increased paperwork and border checks
which many say are adding significant costs
Small businesses have been disproportionately affected
Some have stopped trading with the EU altogether
The government insists Brexit has created new opportunities
with trade deals signed with countries around the world
But independent analysis suggests these deals have not offset EU trade losses
The financial services sector has seen jobs move to European cities
Amsterdam and Dublin have both benefited from London departures
Northern Ireland remains in a unique position
with the Windsor Framework creating a dual market arrangement
This has caused political tensions within the United Kingdom
The fishing industry which was promised great benefits from Brexit
says it has seen very little improvement in practice
Immigration policy has been the most visible change since leaving the EU
Freedom of movement has ended for European citizens
This has created labour shortages in hospitality and agriculture
The food supply chain has been disrupted by new import requirements
Fresh produce now takes longer to reach UK supermarket shelves
The pharmaceutical industry warns of potential medicine shortages
as supply chains are reconfigured to meet new regulatory demands
Public opinion on Brexit remains divided
Recent polls suggest a growing majority now think it was a mistake
But neither major party is proposing to rejoin the European Union
Instead the focus is on making the current arrangements work better
The long term economic impact is still being debated by economists
Some argue Britain will eventually benefit from regulatory freedom
Others say the costs of leaving the single market are permanent
What is beyond dispute is that trade patterns have shifted
and businesses have had to invest heavily in adaptation
The climate agenda intersects with trade policy in complex ways
Carbon border adjustments could create new barriers to trade
Britain outside the EU must navigate these challenges independently
The cost of living crisis has intensified scrutiny of Brexit economics
with food price inflation partly attributed to new trade friction
The next decade will reveal the true scale of the impact
on Britain prosperity and its place in the global economy
For now businesses continue to navigate uncharted waters
